question: Question 6-02/23/2017 Suppose the temperature coefficient of a core is -2.5 × 10^-4 ∆K/K/C and the average control rod worth of the regulating control rod is 5.895 × 10^-3 ∆K/K/inch. If the temperature INCREASES by 50C what will the automatic control command the regulating rod to do? Select the answer that is closest to the calculated value.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: The temperature increase will result in a change in reactivity of: -2.5 × 10^-4 ∆K/K/C × 50C = -1.25 × 10^-2 ∆K/K. Since the temperature rise results in a negative reactivity insertion, the control rod will need to drive out to add positive reactivity. D = (1.25 × 10^-2 ∆K/K) ÷ (5.895 × 10^-3 ∆K/K/inch) = 2.12 inches
Correct.

Incorrect. REF: The temperature increase will result in a change in reactivity of: -2.5 × 10^-4 ∆K/K/C × 50C = -1.25 × 10^-2 ∆K/K. Since the temperature rise results in a negative reactivity insertion, the control rod will need to drive out to add positive reactivity. D = (1.25 × 10^-2 ∆K/K) ÷ (5.895 × 10^-3 ∆K/K/inch) = 2.12 inches

Incorrect. REF: The temperature increase will result in a change in reactivity of: -2.5 × 10^-4 ∆K/K/C × 50C = -1.25 × 10^-2 ∆K/K. question: Question 7-02/23/2017 Which one of the following describes how delayed neutrons affect control of the reactor?

answers.answer: a. More delayed neutrons are produced than prompt neutrons resulting in a longer time to reach a stable subcritical countrate.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.20, p. 236.

answers.answer: b. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energies than prompt neutrons resulting in a shorter reactor period from increased leakage.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.20, p. 236.

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons take longer to thermalize than prompt neutrons resulting in a longer reactor period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Glasstone, S. and Sesonske, A, Nuclear Reactor Engineering, Kreiger Publishing, Malabar, Florida, 1991, § 5.20, p. 236.

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron lifetime resulting in a longer reactor period.
answers.feedback: Correct.
